posts.cooked: This can be from literally any subgroup, from Cad design to outreach. Can also be more general. I’ve used the NASA rap sheet, but I’m looking to see if there are other well used ones. Can also be videos, YouTube channels, anything.

posts.cooked:

link_counts.title: What should new teams be doing?

posts.name: Anderson Hall
posts.cooked: +1 for anything with spectrum. They have a lot more than just training materials as well.

posts.name: Ronan Melville
posts.cooked:
If your team is using Onshape for CAD I reccomend checking out their built in learning center and if your team is not using Onshape for CAD I’d consider switching over. They have some nice self paced courses and even courses made for FRC .

If you have students that are brand new to programming I reccomend trying out the University of Helsinki’s free programming course

1678 also publishes a great set of workshops every year that cover all kinds of topics

Spectrum also has a great video about design organization along with many other helpful videos

I’d also highly reccomend checking out some Open Alliance build logs from both this year and previous years. Some of my favorites from this year:

6328 - Mechanical Advantage

3847 - Spectrum

7407 - Wired Boars

3467 - Windham Windup

link_counts.title: FRC 7407 Wired Boars | 2024 Build Thread | Open Alliance

posts.cooked: Karthik’s Effective FIRST Strategies presentation has a lot of information about strategy, strategic design, and scouting: Karthik: Effective FIRST Strategies 2024 - Championship Conference .

link_counts.title: Karthik: Effective FIRST Strategies 2024 - Championship Conference

posts.name: AllenGregoryIV
posts.cooked:
Resources.spectrum3847.org

and

This Doc is private

have all of the guides we have created and links to many other team’s resources as well.

For programming, one of the resources I started with that helped me a lot was a YouTube channel named FRC 0 to Autonomous. They only have 6 videos, and you need to know a little bit about Java programming with FRC first, but it provides some good information to get started and get deeper. I especially recommend their explanation of PID , as it’s very clear and concise, even for me, who knew nothing about it at the time.

Share your videos with friends, family, and the world

posts.name: Ian
posts.cooked: Here are some docs 2024 rookies have put together; interesting perspective because it’s directly what other rookies have found valuable. FRC 9477 (Lambda) has this: https://roboticslhs.wixsite.com/lambert-robotics/lambda-resources FRC 9496 (Lynk) has this: https://docs.lynkrobotics.org/

posts.cooked: Thanks all. Does anyone have anything on the business/outreach side of things? I haven’t really seen anything.

posts.name: Carlos Salazar
posts.cooked:
In the last offseason, 1678 released some great resources that I shared with a lot of the newer members of our team.

1678 Citrus Circuits Training Resources Release Robotics Education and Curriculum

posts.name: Lance Handkammer
posts.cooked: Yeti (3506) robotics has a series of YouTube tutorials that detail and demonstrate how to effectively design and build west coast drive. I know that west coast has kind of fallen off and become a less popular drive base but if your team is considering using a west coast drive base then I would recommend those videos as they are super helpful.

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked:
A lot of people have provided good resources.

The number one thing I think is important for a rookie team is to find a strong experienced team in their area and work closely with them. The problem for rookie teams without FRC experience is that you’re starting from such a knowledge deficit that you won’t know which resources are most helpful and applicable to you. They can teach how successful FRC teams operate (i.e. it’s more than building a robot), and identify areas where you can make easy improvements, and help shore up areas where you don’t have knowledge.

The senior mentor in your area will probably be the best way to find a team with the capacity to help you.

A lot of what is most important for a rookie team isn’t knowledge about how to build a robot but more knowledge about how to build and run a team. To this end, I’d recommend three resources:

Spectrum’s FIRST $10000, which has a list of tools to buy for a new team.

Spectrum’s FIRST $10000, which has a list of tools to buy for a new team.

1678’s Strategic Design talk, which will walk you through how 1678 approaches the season.

1678’s Strategic Design talk, which will walk you through how 1678 approaches the season.

Mike Corsetto’s Building a Student Leadership Culture talk, which will walk you through how 1678 approaches team leadership. This one might be more important after your rookie year.

Mike Corsetto’s Building a Student Leadership Culture talk, which will walk you through how 1678 approaches team leadership. This one might be more important after your rookie year.
